Award.AwardTitle: TUES: A Laboratory-based Undergraduate Course in Hybrid and Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION

This project is developing a course and a series of 10 laboratory modules that help familiarize students with the technology associated with hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) and plug-in electric vehicles (PEVs). The course builds on prior efforts at the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) involving team competitions and summer REU program experiences in the design, building and testing of hybrid vehicles and addresses an important need to enhance the teaching of alternative energy technologies. The project is employing a strategy of first implementing the new course at IIT and then in another institution that does not have a strength in the HEV/PEV area. This laudable strategy is providing an important opportunity to understand how the material transfers to another educational environment.


BROADER SIGNIFICANCE

The course and coupled laboratory modules span the range of technologies required for hybrid vehicle design, development and implementation/function, which have the potential to be shared in full, or in part, with other HEV/PHEV programs across the country. The project is also promoting the involvement of local high schools and community colleges - through outreach efforts that specifically target diverse populations. The involvement of industrial partners is both maximizing the intellectual resources available to students and enhancing their ability to see a direct impact of the hybrid technologies in an industrial setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Automotive technology has advanced significantly over the past decade. Conventional gasoline-powered engines are typically known to have efficiency in the order of 20% to 30%. Recent advancements in power electronics, energy storage and motor drives have resulted in the development of Hybrid Electric Vehicles (HEV), Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEV) and Electric Vehicles (EV), which include a higher capacity battery with an off-the-wall charging capability. The current project develops a lab-based undergraduate course in the area of HEVs and EVs. The course structure, mini projects, term projects and laboratory experiments encourage students to think critically, analyze and solve complex, real world problems; use appropriate learning resources; work in teams and small groups; demonstrate effective verbal and written communication skills; and use content knowledge and intellectual skills to become continual learners.

A combination of simulation and hardware laboratory experiments were developed from this project. Two powertrain emulators (Series HEV and EV) were designed including the battery, motor and power electronics connected using CAN communication. This setup was used to explain both fundamental and complex concepts in the vehicle, such as motoring, regenerative braking, V2G, battery charging and discharging and so on. Five scaled-down controller modules were developed for allowing students to develop and implement their own control strategies on a real test setup. This unit is very small and can easily be integrated into any existing course in electronics, controls, signal processing, power electronics or motor drives. Students learnt concepts of sampling rate, frequency, feedback controllers and signal processing and demonstrate their effort using real hardware and quantifiable data.

In order to evaluate the effectiveness of the setups in preparing students to join the workforce, industry partners provided feedback was sought as each milestone was accomplished. Some of the key strengths of the lab module include-

1) Modularity: Allows seamless integration into most existing courses or a complete new course on HEVs.

2) Flexibility: Can be used to develop their own control structure and test it on a scaled-down, simplified version of a powertrain.

3) Technical Insight: Allows manipulation of all parameters of a vehicle drivetrain. This gives them valuable insight into the transient and steady state behavior in HEV and EV systems.

 

This project has been very successful and has received a very enthusiastic response from students and faculty (at IIT, UMD and other universities) alike. Other than IIT, this lab setup (partial or full) has been adopted by two Universities- University of Maryland at College Park and Miami University in Ohio. The laboratory prototype was made available to any university interested in adopting this course through the commercialization partner- JW Power, LLC. The PI made detailed information about the lab prototype, manuals and course information available.

 

The main Intellectual merit of this proposal is to provide students with a strong academic background and hands on laboratory-based experience focused on energy-efficient hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs). Although the area of HEVs and PHEVs has been an active area of research for several years, there has not been a course structure that introduces these concepts to students as part of their curriculum. The laboratory-based course developed is a brand new effort to integrate emerging topics to classroom education and disseminate the experience to other educational institutions.
